stems: In your next class you will take part in a discussion led by your tutor.
For your case study discussion, you should only use the information given in this lesson.
You can use notes in discussions.
Speaking is the most important skill in a discussion.
According to the speaker, using discussion language accurately is the most important way to contribute effectively to a discussion.
data.stimulus:
In this video, Rachel reviews what students can expect from academic discussions and explains the format of your case study discussion.

► Listen and answer the questions below:

list: The most important purpose of a chairperson is to ensure that the participants of a meeting follow ...
... the brief and stay on topic, respect each other and the rules of the meeting.
The chairperson starts the meeting, welcomes everyone and states what the topic is. They must...
... manage the time, introduce each section of the agenda as they move through it, and make sure there is time to discuss each subtopic.
The chairperson should allow all those attending the meeting to have a chance to express their views and opinions. They should be ...
... friendly and encourage those present to participate during the meeting and make all members feel welcomed and valued.
Finally, the chair also has an important role encouraging quieter members to contribute.
data.stimulus:
In this video, Sean reviews the role of the chairperson and gives you some useful advice for participating in discussions.

► Organise the summary of the chairperson's responsibilities below into the correct order.

In the questions below, you will review some useful language for chairing a discussion...

 

1. Language for starting the discussion 

► Put the words into the correct order:

2. Language for managing contributions 

► Put the words into the correct order:

3. Language for for inviting participants to contribute 

► Put the words into the correct order:

value: The point I'd like to make is...
I don't see it that way
I agree up to a point, but...

possible_responses: The point I'd like to make is...
I don't see it that way
I agree up to a point, but...
data.stimulus:
Next, let's review some useful language for everyone in a discussion.

 

Below are different phrases participants might use in a discussion.

► Place them in the correct box.

value: The point I'd like to make is...
I don't see it that way
I agree up to a point, but...

data.template:
At the end of your assessed group discussion, {{response}} of the group will be asked to summarise {{response}} of the discussion based on their notes.

► Let's look at an example of a discussion summary.

data.stimulus:
A group of students took part in the following discussion:

At the end of the discussion, one student gave a summary of the key points.

► Read the summary and choose the appropriate verb

(make a note of the useful language for when you do a summary!)
data.template:
STAGE 1: INTRODUCE THE SUMMARY
"So, let’s review what we’ve {{response}} today"
 
STAGE 2: RE-STATE THE TOPIC
"In today's discussion, we {{response}} about our experiences of giving presentations and then we {{response}} the most important features of an effective presentation".
 
STAGE 3: THE SUMMARY
"First, members of the group {{response}} different experience of giving presentations. Most had given a presentation before and a few had also given presentations in English. These included presentations at university and at work
We also {{response}} different opinions about whether giving presentations was easy or difficult. We {{response}} about how this often depended on the topic and the personality of the speaker, for example academic presentations were more difficult than non-academic ones, and shy speakers found presenting more difficult than confident speakers. However, everyone {{response}} that giving a presentation in English was challenging.
Next, we {{response}} preparation. Everyone {{response}} that research was important, especially when preparing for academic presentations. One student {{response}} out the importance of making a note of sources. We also {{response}}  practising. Some students recorded themselves, while others practised with friends. One member of the group {{response}} an interesting point that practising confident body language could help nervous speakers.
Finally, we all {{response}} that, the most important feature of a presentation was that it was interesting to the audience. We also {{response}} that to make it interesting, we needed to focus on content, and clear language and delivery".
 
STAGE 4: ENDING THE SUMMARY
"Thank you everyone for taking part today. Does anyone want to {{response}} anything?"

data.stimulus:
In this part of today's lesson, you are going to prepare for your Case Study Discussion.

► First, we'll look at some vocabulary collocations which will be useful for this task. 

 

 

The topic is Brand Management. 

► Each of the words below collocates with BRAND, PRODUCT or MARKET to form word partnerships. 

► Drag and drop to form the correct collocations. 

 

(you can use each word FOUR times)
data.template:
{{response}} share

{{response}} endorsement

{{response}} image

{{response}} loyalty

 {{response}} name

{{response}} range

 {{response}} research

{{response}} awareness

{{response}} segment

{{response}} launch

{{response}} leader

{{response}} placement

data.stimulus: Now match the collocations to the right definition.
data.template:
• {{response}} - the title given to a product by the company that makes it.
  • {{response}} - the ideas and beliefs people have about a brand.
  • {{response}} - the tendency to always buy a particular brand.
  • {{response}} - how familiar people are with a brand (or its logo and slogan).

 

  • {{response}} - the set of products made by a company.
  • {{response}} - the use of a well-known person to advertise products.
  • {{response}} - when products are used in films or TV programmes.
  • {{response}} - the introduction of a product to the market.

 

  • {{response}} - the percentage of sales a company has.
  • {{response}} - customers of a similar age, income level or social group.
  • {{response}} - the best-selling product or brand in a market.
  • {{response}} - information about what consumers want or need.

data.stimulus:
To finish up this vocabulary section, let's look at these words in context. 

► Complete each sentence with the missing word (drag and drop).
data.template:
1. No one recognises our logo or slogan. We need to spend more on advertising to raise {{response}}.
  2. Consumers who always buy Apple when they need a new mobile are showing {{response}}. 
  3. The {{response}} of Mercedes-Benz is such that its products are seen as safe, reliable, luxurious, well made and expensive.
  4. The actor George Clooney advertising Nespresso is an example of {{response}}.
  5. Tesco's wide {{response}} means that it appeals to all sectors of the UK market.
  6. The use of Aston Martin cars and Sony computers in James Bond films are examples of {{response}}. 
  7. Microsoft is the {{response}} in computer software.
  8. In countries with ageing populations, the over-60s age group is becoming an increasingly important {{response}}.
  9. Focus groups and consumer surveys are ways of conducting {{response}}.

options.label: They don't have an office in Europe.
They don't have a warehouse in Europe.
The brand is not well-known in the USA.
The brand is not well-known in Europe.
They don’t know the European market as well as the US market.
They may face different and new competitors.
The products may not match the European consumers’ tastes.

data.stimulus:
Next, read the company profile and answer the question below.

Company Profile

Hudson Corporation, based in New Jersey, USA, makes top-of-the-range luggage and travel accessories. It is a well-known brand name in the USA. Its suitcases and bags are associated with high quality, traditional design and craftsmanship.

Hudson emphasises in its advertising that its products are 'made in America'. Recently, the company's market share in the USA has decreased. One reason for this has been the increased competition from Asian companies selling similar products at much lower prices.

A year ago, the management decided to boost sales by entering the European market, focusing initially on Switzerland, Germany, France and Italy. They set up an office and warehouse facility in Zurich, which would be the base for their European expansion.

 

What PROBLEMS might Hudson Corporation face in its expansion to Europe?

(Choose FOUR)

The company carried out a survey to find out how consumers perceived the company's brand in the USA.

► Here are the results:

► Complete the findings below:

Get Ready to Listen

Listen to four Hudson managers talking about the problems they could face in Europe.

 

► Complete the meeting main points below.
data.template:
Today's Meeting - Main Points:

  • Diana: Hudson will have to do a lot of {{response}}. They may need to adapt their products for the European  consumers.
  • Ruth: They have to get the {{response}} right: Europeans are less {{response}} than Americans so they can charge high prices if they position the brand in the luxury goods market.
  • Tom: They should go {{response}}, reduce the price and reduce costs – stop {{response}} in the US. 
  • Last speaker: Increase {{response}}and stretch the brand. Hudson needs new {{response}}.
